channel.title: NYT > Obituaries
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Virginia Oliver, Maine’s ‘Lobster Lady’ and Folk Hero, Dies at 105
item.description: She fished off the New England coast for more than 80 years, and intended to continue until she died. “It’s not hard work for me,” she said at 101.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald
item.media:description: Ms. Oliver in 2021, when she was 101. “She represented that no-nonsense Mainer who just got up every day and did what they had to do,” said Barbara Walsh, the author of a children’s book about Mrs. Oliver.

item.title: Tom Britt, Designer of Larger-Than-Life Interiors, Dies at 89
item.description: A master of the grand gesture, he was as theatrical as his rooms, which were inspired by French chateaus and Italian palazzos. As he put it, “Why be ordinary?”
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green

item.title: Chuck Negron, Hitmaking Singer With Three Dog Night, Dies at 83
item.description: His tenor anchored generational hits like “Joy to the World” and “One” by one of pop music’s commercial powerhouses of the early 1970s.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams and Ali Watkins
item.media:description: Three Dog Night in 1971. From left, Danny Hutton, Chuck Negron and Cory Wells. They were one of the entertainment world’s most bankable acts from 1969 to 1975, turning out 21 Billboard Top 40 singles, including 11 in the Top 10.

item.title: Michael Parenti, Unapologetic Marxist Theorist and Author, Dies at 92
item.description: A prolific writer and lecturer, he viewed U.S. history through the lens of class struggle. But some accused him of defending brutal regimes in the Soviet Union and Serbia.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Inventing Reality: The Politics of the Mass Media (Book)
item.media:credit: Herb Snitzer, via Michael Ochs Archive,/Getty Images
item.media:description: Michael Parenti in 1999. A feisty lecturer and critic of the mainstream media, he often took positions that few others on the American left would take.

item.title: John Forté, Who Forged a Hip-Hop Redemption Tale, Dies at 50
item.description: He seemed destined for a glittering career, working with the Fugees and solo, and then landed in prison. After his sentence was commuted, he clawed his way back.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:description: John Forté in 2010. His rise in the music industry was swift, but his fall came just as quickly, when he was convicted of acting as a middleman in a scheme to transport $1.4 million worth of liquid cocaine.

item.title: Woodie King Jr., a Driving Force in Black Theater, Dies at 88
item.description: His New Federal Theater in New York provided a rare stage for Black playwrights and emerging actors, among them Denzel Washington, Phylicia Rashad and Chadwick Boseman.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.category: For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf (Play)
item.media:credit: Aaron Lee Fineman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Woodie King Jr. in 2004 in front of the New Federal Theater in the Henry Street Playhouse building on Manhattan’s Lower East Side.

item.title: Billy Bass Nelson, Original Bassist for Funkadelic, Dies at 75
item.description: George Clinton, while working as a barber, recruited him. Mr. Nelson went on to name the group and, with his bandmates, to be inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum
item.media:description: Billy Bass Nelson, seated at far right, with other members of Funkadelic in 1971.

item.title: James Sallis, 81, Dies; Novelist Whose ‘Drive’ Became a Hit Movie
item.description: A storyteller of modern America’s underbelly with a literary, ruminative style, he inspired a Ryan Gosling movie and earned critical acclaim.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.media:description: The crime novelist James Sallis in 2013. One critic said of him that he “writes in the tradition of Raymond Chandler, albeit via Albert Camus.”

item.title: X.J. Kennedy, a Poet of Wit Who Clung to Rhyme and Meter, Dies at 96
item.description: Spurning the free verse of many of his contemporaries, he held to an older tradition. He also wrote spirited poems for children.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Chace

item.title: Robert Pratt, Federal Judge Who Derided Trump Pardons, Dies at 78
item.description: He was chastised for remarks ridiculing the pardons of two congressional campaign aides who had been convicted in a bribery plot.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:credit: Mark Kegans for The New York Times
item.media:description: Judge Robert Pratt in 2006. He spent 26 years on the federal bench in Iowa, issuing several important rulings.

item.title: T. Kumar, Rights Activist Who Was Shaped by Time in Prison, Dies at 76
item.description: After being jailed as a resistance organizer for the Tamil minority in his native Sri Lanka, he spoke out against governmental repression worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Laura Maioglio, Whose Restaurant Is a Theater District Mainstay, Dies at 93
item.description: Since 1962, she oversaw her father’s stately Italian restaurant, Barbetta, and became one of the city’s most enduring female restaurateurs.
item.dc:creator: Julie Besonen
item.media:description: Laura Maioglio in 1999. In 1996, the Italian government awarded Barbetta the Insegna del Ristorante Italiano, in recognition for serving the best authentic Italian food outside Italy.

item.title: Demond Wilson, Long-Suffering Son on ‘Sanford and Son,’ Dies at 79
item.description: As Lamont, he was a young man in constant battle with his father and business partner, played by Redd Foxx, on the popular 1970s series.
item.dc:creator: Anita Gates
item.media:credit: NBCU Photo Bank, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Mr. Wilson, left, in 1972 on “Sanford and Son” with Redd Foxx, who played his character’s father.

item.title: Overlooked No More: Jimmy Reed, the Bluesman Everyone Covered, Then Forgot
item.description: His most enduring hits were recorded by Elvis Presley, Aretha Franklin, the Rolling Stones and the Grateful Dead. But his own career faded from view.
item.dc:creator: Bill Friskics-Warren
item.media:description: Jimmy Reed performing in 1968. He built a bridge between rock and the blues, placing 12 singles on the pop chart as well as 18 in the R&B Top 20.

item.title: Morris Waxler, F.D.A. Official Who Switched Stance on Lasik, Dies at 88
item.description: While at the federal agency, he approved the laser device for eye surgery but later warned of its potential to cause harm.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: Dan McQuade, a Catalyst in Cosby’s Downfall, Dies at 43
item.description: His viral video of the comedian Hannibal Buress calling Bill Cosby a rapist helped spur broader coverage of sexual-assault accusations against a once-beloved entertainer.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman

item.title: ‘Produce Pete’ Napolitano, a Fruit and Vegetable Celebrity, Dies at 80
item.description: For more than 30 years, he drew fans for dispensing weekly produce punditry on a New York television station, building on a sales career that began when he was 5.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:credit: Chris Maynard for The New York Times
item.media:description: Peter Napolitano at his produce store in Bergenfield, N.J., in 2004. He offered advice about produce on a Saturday morning news program, reporting from farms, restaurants, pumpkin patches and corn fields.

item.title: Macaulay Culkin And Others Pay Tribute to Catherine O’Hara After Her Death
item.description: Videos and photos filled social media as fans shared their favorite scenes from O’Hara’s acting career and co-stars memorialized her.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.media:description: Catherine O’Hara in 2019. The actress died this week at the age of 71.

item.title: Roger Allers Dies at 76; Helped Put ‘Lion King’ on Screens and Onstage
item.description: A Disney fan who once “flew” off his couch as a 4-year-old Peter Pan, he was a co-director of the animated film and a co-writer of the Broadway musical, both of them megahits.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: Roger Allers in 2023. “He was extraordinarily visual, had a great story sense and a beautiful design sense,” a colleague said.

item.title: Björn Roth, Steward of an Expansive Family Art Practice, Dies at 64
item.description: With his father, the artist Dieter Roth, and later his own sons, he created unconventional installations that he described as a “search for beauty in nothing.”
item.dc:creator: Will Heinrich
item.media:description: Björn Roth in 2013 with a chocolate bust of his father, Dieter Roth — one of hundreds that made up “Self Tower,” a piece created for “Dieter Roth Björn Roth,” a show at Hauser & Wirth in Manhattan.

item.title: Catherine O’Hara, ‘Home Alone’ and ‘Schitt’s Creek’ Actress, Dies at 71
item.description: An Emmy-winning comedian with oddball charm, she got her start with the influential Canadian sketch comedy series “SCTV.”
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams and Rylee Kirk
item.media:credit: Ryan Pfluger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Catherine O’Hara in 2019.

item.title: Michael Beck, 65, Dies; First to Report Symptoms of ‘Havana Syndrome’
item.description: As an employee with the N.S.A., he claimed he was exposed to a direct-energy device that led to a diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease at the age of 45.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Katherine Frey/The Washington Post, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Michael Beck in 2017. He said he began experiencing debilitating symptoms of Havana Syndrome much earlier than many other federal employees.

item.title: John L. Allen Jr., Journalist With Inside Access to the Vatican, Dies at 61
item.description: He seemed to know everyone at the Holy See, and it showed in his reporting for the National Catholic Reporter and his website, Crux, though some said he grew too close to his sources.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:credit: Karen Warren/Houston Chronicle, via Getty Images
item.media:description: John L. Allen Jr. in 2007. “From the end of the 20th century until his death, Allen was essential reading for anyone who cared about the inner workings of the Vatican,” a colleague said.

item.title: Shirley Raines, 58, Who Gave L.A.’s Homeless Food and Makeovers, Dies
item.description: Her work feeding people and dyeing their hair through her nonprofit, Beauty 2 the Streetz, was known to millions online.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shirley Raines in Los Angeles in 2023.

item.title: Angella Ferguson, a Leader in Sickle Cell Anemia Research, Dies at 100
item.description: A Black female doctor when that was rare, she developed a diagnostic test for the disease that is still a standard tool, as well as treatment guidelines.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: Geoff Mason, Sports Producer Thrust Into Covering Terrorism, Dies at 85
item.description: He played a critical role in ABC Sports’s reporting on the attack by a Palestinian group at the 1972 Summer Games in Munich that left 11 Israeli team members dead.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:credit: American Broadcasting Companies, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Geoffrey Mason, with ABC Sports, at the 1988 Winter Olympics in Alberta, Canada. He won 24 Emmy Awards for producing coverage of sports events.

item.title: Sly Dunbar, Whose Drumming Brought Complex Beats to Reggae, Dies at 73
item.description: As one half of the famed rhythm duo Sly and Robbie, he played with some of the biggest names in music, including Bob Dylan and Mick Jagger.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Sly Dunbar in 2014. Rolling Stone ranked him No. 65 in its list of the 100 greatest drummers of all time and, because he was widely sampled, “quite possibly the world’s most recorded musician.”
